title: Client Report - [Insert Project Title]
text:
QUESTION|TASK 1
COPY PASTE QUESTION|TASK 1 FROM THE PROJECT HERE
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here


include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.
::: {#cell-Q1 chart .cell execution_count=4}

plot example
# Include and execute your code here
chart = px.bar(df.head(200),
    x="name", 
    y="AK"
)
chart.show()


                                                
My useless chart

:::
::: {#cell-Q1 table .cell .tbl-cap-location-top tbl-cap=‘Not much of a table’ execution_count=5}

table example
# Include and execute your code here
mydat = df.head(1000)\
    .groupby('year')\
    .sum()\
    .reset_index()\
    .tail(10)\
    .filter(["year", "AK","AR"])

display(mydat)

title: Client Report - [US name history index]
text:
This project is a result of the query method in pandas. With the prompts provided, I have made graphs to visualize the data. Answering the questions, I have learned that names through time change in use based on fads/trends. The use of a name can go down and up in time.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")

title: Client Report - [US name history index]
text:
This project is a result of the query method in pandas. With the prompts provided, I have made graphs to visualize the data. Answering the questions, I have learned that names through time change in use based on fads/trends. The use of a name can go down and up in time.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")

title: Client Report - [US name history index]
text:
QUESTION|TASK 1
How does your name at your birth year compare to its use historically?
My Birthyear was about the halfway point of the peakvuse of the name Cannon.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
cannon = px.line(df.query('name == "Cannon"'), x="year", y="Total", title="Cannons naming history")
cannon.add_annotation(x=2005, y=208, text="My Birthyear")
cannon.show()


                                                


::: {#cell-Q1 table .cell .tbl-cap-location-top tbl-cap=‘Not much of a table’ execution_count=4}

table example
# Include and execute your code here
mydat = df.head(1000)\
    .groupby('year')\
    .sum()\
    .reset_index()\
    .tail(10)\
    .filter(["year", "AK","AR"])

display(mydat)









year
AK
AR




96
2006
21.0
183.0


97
2007
28.0
153.0


98
2008
36.0
212.0


99
2009
34.0
179.0


100

:::

title: Client Report - [US name history index]
text:
QUESTION|TASK 2
If you talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, what is your guess of his or her age? What ages would you not guess?
I would guess the age of Brittany to be 33 because of the amount of people named Brittany in 1990. I would not guess 55-56 because of the 5 people named Brittany then.


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
brit = px.line(df.query('name == "Brittany"'), x="year", y="Total")
brit.add_annotation(x=1990, y=32562, text="33 to 34")
brit.add_annotation(x=1968, y=5, text="55 to 56")
brit.show()


                                                


::: {#cell-Q2 chart .cell execution_count=6}

plot example
# Include and execute your code here
chart = px.bar(df.head(200),
    x="name", 
    y="AK"
)
chart.show()

title: Client Report - [US name history index]
text:
QUESTION|TASK 3
Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul are all Christian names. From 1920 - 2000, compare the name usage of each of the four names. What trends do you notice?
from 1920-1968 Mary was the most common name of the four. But in 1968, Paul passed slightly, than they were close ever since.The use of Martha has been lowest since 1954


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
christian = px.line(df.query('(name == "Peter" or name == "Paul" or name == "Martha" or name == "Mary") and 1919 < year < 2001'), x="year", y="Total", color="name")
christian.show()


                                                


::: {#cell-Q3 table .cell .tbl-cap-location-top tbl-cap=‘Not much of a table’ execution_count=9}

table example
# Include and execute your code here
mydat = df.head(1000)\
    .groupby('year')\
    .sum()\
    .reset_index()\
    .tail(10)\
    .filter(["year", "AK","AR"])

display(mydat)









year
AK
AR

183.0


97
2007
28.0
153.0


98

36.0
212.0


99
2009
34.0

title: Client Report - [US name history index]
text:
QUESTION|TASK 4
Think of a unique name from a famous movie. Plot the usage of that name and see how changes line up with the movie release. Does it look like the movie had an effect on usage?
The graph below shoes the history of all people named Anakin. The first starwars movie came out in 1977. Before 1998 there was never someone named Anakin in the database. The star wars movies lead to people being named Anakin


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
starwars = px.line(df.query('name == "Anakin"'), x="year", y="Total")
starwars.show()
